channel.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
channel.description:
http://steamcommunity.com/workshop/aboutpaidcontent/
Who else thinks this is bullshit? The amount of free mods is going to drop tremendously, and unless you want to pay for some half-assed map or weapon or something, you don't get to mod your game.

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“relmitos, post:17, topic:551211”]A 75% cut of the profit, lol what?
A 25% commission would seem more reasonable.[/quote]its gone. they dropped the idea. let’s stop discussing this horrible marketing attempt

Read full topic

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:11, topic:551211”]My attitude is that it’s wrong to charge for something you did to something you didn’t make. You’d never see people charging for level editors or other utilities used to modify games because I do believe public reverse engineering of copyrighted work wasn’t exactly legal. However, I guess you could look at it as charging to fix someone’s car or installing a custom stereo. I don’t see why programming couldn’t be the same way if the original developers are okay with it.[/quote]Watch totalbiscuits video about the issue, he discusses that exact point in the first couple minutes.

tl;dw - This system works directly with the game publisher to not only allow people to use their assets to create mods, but the publisher gets a cut of the profit that steam takes from mod sales. This is why the trial is just for skyrim, Bethesda was the first company they worked out a contract with

Read full topic
item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

My attitude is that it’s wrong to charge for something you did to something you didn’t make. You’d never see people charging for level editors or other utilities used to modify games because I do believe public reverse engineering of copyrighted work wasn’t exactly legal. However, I guess you could look at it as charging to fix someone’s car or installing a custom stereo. I don’t see why programming couldn’t be the same way if the original developers are okay with it.

Read full topic
item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Davidi2:

However, after reading about the system, it appears valve has not taken the proper measures to ensure its the actual content creators putting items up. People are taking credit for publicly released mods and trying to sell them. There needs to be an intense approval system for it.

I wonder if Valve is gonna try to pawn alot of these responsibility off on the game publisher/developers that the workshops are for… They seem to only be concerned with the monies these days.

Read full topic
item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

In some cases mods make the game what it is (I’m looking at you Minecraft), so why shouldn’t people be able to get paid for their work? And you a refund if you’re not happy, so little chance of people exploiting the system by making lots of promises and fail to deliver.

Read full topic
item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Davidi2:

You get higher quality mods, and people that spend a lot of time modding can now get compensated for their work. People that do it for fun will still make it free.

Sure they will, it’s the same concept as open source software but I still don’t like that half the games I buy because they have workshop I won’t be able to enjoy as much because of all the paid content…

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:6, topic:551211”]I think it’s a good idea in the long run. People put work into some of those mods… It’s only fair they get some payment for them.

Sure, it’s going to suck if/when 90% of the mods become paid. and then you’re stuck with slim pickings for the free ones. But overall, it’s a good thing.[/quote]
Eh. I myself actually have a couple of Garry’s Mod workshop weapons, would I like to make money off them? Of course, who doesn’t like making money, however, would I want to be the other user having to pay for workshop addons in a game that I also payed money for? No. I would not. It would also probably take me down from the like 20k downloads I got to around a couple ten… Maybe it will work good in certain games, like Skyrim, the original version. I’m partial because when I think of workshop, the first thing that comes to mind is Gmod, which paid workshop items spell danger for the entire community of it, with all the kids running around making half assed items and making money for it, wouldn’t even be able to download these things for more then 24 hours and laugh and the glitches with your friends…

Read full topic
item.source: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods

item.title: Steam Now Allowing Workshop Creators To Charge For Mods
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I think it’s a good idea in the long run. People put work into some of those mods… It’s only fair they get some payment for them.

Sure, it’s going to suck if/when 90% of the mods become paid. and then you’re stuck with slim pickings for the free ones. But overall, it’s a good thing.

Read full topic
